descriptions.content:
The namtar style and Modern Literary Tibetan both use auxiliaries that are formally identical to those of the spoken language, but they function differently from their oral homologues.

Namtar Style

Tense

Auxiliaries

Past

Verb (past) + སོང་ (distancing), Verb (past) + བྱུང་ (nearing)

Verb (past) + པ་ཡིན་, Verb (past) + ཡོད་, Verb (past) + འདུག་

Present

Verb (present) + གི་འདུག་, Verb (present) + གི་ཡོད་

Verb (present) + གི་ཡོད་པ་རེད་, Verb (present) + བཞིན་འདུག་

Verb (present) + བཞིན་ཡོད་, Verb (present) + ཅིང་འདུག་

Verb (present) + ཅིང་ཡོད་, Verb (present) + གིན་འདུག་

Verb (present) + གིན་ཡོད་

Future

Verb (present / future) + རྒྱུ་ཡིན་, Verb (present / future) + པ་ཡིན་

The verbal system used in namtar will not be described in detail here.[1] It should, however, be pointed out that, unlike their homologues in the spoken language, these auxiliaries do not convey evidential moods[2] (or “mediatory” moods): they provide only information relating to tense and aspect. Even in Modern Literary Tibetan, with the exception of writings that reproduce the spoken language, the distinction between the first person (egophoric) and the others is generally not relevant, nor is that between intentional and unintentional, as the following sentence shows:

  • དྭངས་གསལ་སེམས་ཀྱི་མེ་ལོང་གཙང་མ་ལ། འཆི་བདག་རྒྱལ་པོའི་ཁ་རླངས་ཕོག་པ་ཡིན། “The pure mirror of the clear mind is touched by the breath of the Lord of the Dead.”

In this example, the auxiliary པ་ཡིན་ is used with a non-volitional verb ཕོག་ “to be touched” in the third person. In Spoken Tibetan, this auxiliary is always used in association with the first person of a volitional verb.

Finally, it should be noted that there is a difference with regard to negation. In Literary Tibetan, the use of the particles of negation མ་ and མི་ depends on tense-aspect and mood: མི་ is used with the present (or the imperfective past, which is similar to the present), whereas མ་ is used with the past (perfective) and the imperative (the negative form of the imperative is similar to the present).

  • འགྲོ་མ་ཐུབ། “(He) could not go.”
  • འགྲོ་མི་ཐུབ། “(He) can not go.”
  • སྨན་པ་དང་མོ་མ་རྣམས་ཀྱིས་ཀྱང་མི་འཚོ་བར་ལུང་བསྟན་ཞིང་བོར། “The physicians and the diviners prophesied that he would not survive, and abandoned him.”

Here the use of the negation མི་ reveals that we are dealing with the future (from the point of view of the past).

This rule doesn’t apply in the spoken language, since མ་ and མི་ don’t depend on tense but on the type of auxiliary that is used (cf. འདུག་ > མི་འདུག་ and ཡོད་རེད་ > ཡོད་མ་རེད་).

[1] See Kesang Gyurmé, Le Clair Miroir: Enseignement de la Grammaire Tibétaine, translation and commentaries by Heather Stoddard and Nicolas Tournadre, 2nd edition (Arvillard: Editions Prajñā, 1994).

[2] It should be remembered that the originality of the system of ﬁnal auxiliary verbs in Spoken Tibetan lies not only in the indications of tense and aspect that they provide, but also in various “mediatory” moods (xxlink MST 5.3.2) that specify the source of information used by the speaker to characterize a statement: egophoric, assertive, testimonial, and inferential.
